docs.lead_paragraph: THE UNABRIDGED JOURNALS OF SYLVIA PLATH: 1950-1962 Edited by Karen V. Kukil 732 pages. Anchor Books. $18. In her own poems Sylvia Plath tirelessly mythologized herself as a doomed Electra, a ''Lady Lazarus'' eating ''men like air,'' a Persephone drawn ineluctably toward an underworld of death and despair. In the wake of her 1963 suicide, the mythification continued: feminists eulogized her as a victim of her father and her philandering husband, Ted Hughes, while others enshrined her as a tragic figure -- ''a Dido, Phaedra or Medea'' in the words of Robert Lowell.

headline.main: Charting Terrain on an Internal Landscape

docs.abstract: Michiko Kakutani reviews The Unabridged Journals of Sylvia Plath: 1950-1962; photo (M)
